title-group.article-title: Effects of Food-Related Interventions for African American Women With Type 2 Diabetes

contrib-group.aff: University of Texas at Austin School of Nursing, Austin, Texas

author-notes.corresp: Lisa L. Sumlin, 1700 Red River, Austin, TX 78701 (Lsumlin7@gmail.com).

permissions.copyright-holder: American Association of Diabetes Educators; Published by SAGE Publications

abstract.p: The purpose of this systematic review is to synthesize research that tested culturally competent food-related interventions designed for African American women with type 2 diabetes, to review the current state of the literature and suggest recommendations for future research. Many African American women with type 2 diabetes are challenged to change their culturally rooted food habits to achieve diabetes control. Diabetes educators and clinicians who work with African American women need knowledge of effective interventions to assist their clients.

Online databases and research articles’ reference lists were searched for relevant studies published from 1989 to 2010 that tested culturally competent type 2 diabetes management interventions for African American women, that included at least 1 educational session on diet or nutrition, and that addressed a physiologic outcome, such as glycosylated hemoglobin or fasting blood glucose.

Fifteen studies met the inclusion criteria for this review. Among them, 64% to 100% of the participants were African Americans, and 65% to 100% were women. Six studies showed significant improvements in food practices, and 8 showed significant improvements in glycemic control as a result of the interventions.

Few studies focused solely on helping African American women make culturally relevant dietary changes to control type 2 diabetes. Most interventions addressed food habits as one of many components for diabetes control, perhaps overwhelming research participants with large amounts of varied information. Targeted interventions are recommended that focus on dietary changes as the foundation for diabetes self-management education for African American women.

body.p: African Americans are disproportionately affected by type 2 diabetes (T2DM) in prevalence, disease complications, and cost compared with Caucasian Americans. Over 3.7 million African Americans aged 20 years of age and older have T2DM (14.7%), which is almost double the rate among non-Hispanic whites.1

In 2005, the number of hospital discharges related to diabetes in the general population declined, but for African Americans the number of diabetes-related hospitalizations was 1.5 times higher than for Caucasian Americans.2 The total cost for diabetes was $174 billion, of which $116 billion was related to direct medical costs.2 Since African Americans are hospitalized more often than their Caucasian counterparts, African Americans are likely to accrue more of the total diabetes-related costs.

Dietary change, also called medical nutritional therapy, is recognized as the cornerstone for managing diabetes3 because healthy diets have been found to reduce glycosylated hemoglobin (A1C) up to 2.9% within a 6-month period.4 However, for African America women, dietary modifications are the most difficult lifestyle change to make. Adherence to a healthy diet may be more difficult because traditional African American foods are high fat and salts5-7 and African Americans may have increased consumption of fast food5,8-10 due to its convenience, cost, and availability.

There are several reasons for focusing on African American women’s efforts for dietary changes. Compared to men, women tend to be more engaged in household activities, such as grocery shopping and meal preparation.11 Culturally based food practices are generally carried from one generation to the next through the women.12,13 Therefore, improvements in women’s dietary habits could be adopted by the next generation and decrease future generations’ risk for developing T2DM and related conditions. For these reasons, African American women with T2DM should be helped to make culturally acceptable dietary changes.

The emphasis on cultural competence within health care emerged in 1989 in response to increased diversity within the United States and the recognition that health disparities among minority groups should be addressed with culturally appropriate solutions.14 For African American women, food practices are deeply rooted in cultural history and contribute significantly to their self-identity. Thus, culturally tailored dietary interventions for African American women are foundational to decreasing the negative effects of T2DM. This narrative systematic review of the literature was conducted to describe research published since 1989 that tested culturally competent food-related interventions designed specifically for African American women with T2DM, to identify the most effective interventions and their components. Findings from this review may serve as a foundation for effective clinical practice and future research.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: We conducted a systematic review of published studies that tested culturally specific dietary interventions for African Americans with T2DM. Fink’s criteria15 were used to select studies for appropriateness and methodological quality. Studies were included if they (1) were written in English; (2) used an experimental or quasi-experimental design tested on a sample composed of at least 60% African American adults aged 18 years or older with a diagnosis of T2DM; (3) referred to a culturally competent intervention or approach; (4) described at least 1 education session on diet to control diabetes; (5) tested the intervention’s effect on physiologic outcomes, such as A1C or fasting blood glucose; and (6) were published between 1989 and 2010 (1989 was selected to coincide with the emergence of culturally appropriate solutions to population diversity, which was followed by the establishment of the Office of Minority Health and Research at the National Institutes of Health in 1990). Studies were excluded if they were not specific to African American culture, did not provide specific information on the dietary component of the intervention, or did not report results from the intervention. Qualitative studies were excluded because we were interested in the effect of the interventions on quantitatively measured outcomes, such as dietary behaviors, A1C, and other physiologic measures.

sec.title: Search Strategy
sec.p: The electronic databases searched for this systematic review were PubMed, Cumulative Index to Nursing and Allied Health Literature, the Cochrane Review database, and The Diabetes Educator journal index. Multiple searches were conducted with various search term synonyms to find all relevant studies. The following search terms were used: African American women, African Americans, black women, T2DM, community health worker, adults, diet, nutrition, nutrition interventions, diabetes management, and management. Other sources were obtained from ancestry searches of articles’ reference lists and consultation with colleagues.

sec.title: Data Extraction
sec.p: For data extraction, a chart was developed that included the following information: authors, year, purpose of study, study design, setting, participants (age, sex, percentage of women, education, body mass index, years with diabetes, average A1C at baseline), description of the intervention, measures taken in the study, and major findings (see Table 1). These components were documented from studies for this review, and the components and study findings were examined to identify the most effective components.

caption.p: Research Studies of Culturally Competent Dietary-Based Interventions for African Americans With Type 2 Diabetes (1989-2010)

tr.td: Nutrition
Anderson-Loftin et al22: Test effect of a dietary self-management intervention on physiologic outcomes and dietary behaviors for AA
Quasi-experimental, pretest-posttest control group; 3 primary care practices in South Carolina; 97 AA, 78% and 75% female, mean age 58.9 and 55.7 y, A1C > 7.8, BMI > 25, high-fat diet
4 weekly 1.5-h classes focused on planning, purchasing, preparing healthy low-fat meals, and healthy choices eating out; with group discussions; follow-up by a RN–case manager.
A1C, weight, height, BMI, FHQ (25-item scale measuring food intake), chol

SS changes achieved in lower BMI (P = .009 decr of .81 kg/mm2) and FHQ (P = .005 decr to 2.4), no difference in A1C (P = .518) (started low), weight (women lost 1.5 lb; men gained 5.4 lb), chol (P = .731)
Ziemer et al3: To compare a simple meal plan emphasizing healthy food choices with a transitional exchange-based meal plan in reducing A1C in AA
RCT; Grady Health System diabetes clinic in Atlanta, Georgia; 648, 90% AA, 65% women; mean age 52 y, DM 4.8 y, mean A1C 9.4
Over 6 mo: dietary counseling by RD; initial visit (1 h) and 30 min each subsequent clinic visit (3); planning menus, preparing foods, interpreting food labels, appropriate food choices
FFQ, 24-h recall, Kristal fat screener (fat-containing foods), A1C, changes in weight, lipids, and BP

Both groups: decr fat intake (P = .07), sugar-containing foods (P = .09), mean weight lost (P = .02); lower triglycerides; no changes in the LDL (both groups P = .15) or BP; and HDL incr (P < .001 both groups). A1C (decr 9.7 to 7.8, P = .12 between groups). No difference between groups.
Anderson-Loftin et al23: Dietary self-management intervention to improve physiologic outcomes, DM self-management, and cost of care for AA with type 2 DM
Quasi-experimental, 1-group pretest-posttest. Medically underserved rural county in South Carolina; 23-high-risk AA adults, 73% female, middle age, DM 10 y, 83% obese

Over 9 mo: 4 low-fat dietary education classes; healthy low-fat food choices; food pyramid by RD and RN, followed by 30-min to 1-h peer discussion groups, monthly until end of intervention. Follow-up phone calls, home visits by RN-case manager
FBS, A1C, lipid profile, BMI, BP, adopted Food Habits Questionnaire, cost of care (acute care visits and length of hospital stay)

Decr A1C (P = .0106), FBS (P = .0176), and costs of care (acute care visits, P = .0500), weight loss (mean loss of 5% body weight), and decr chol (reduction of 17%), BP. Significant improvement in dietary habits (P = .005)
Weight management
Skelly et al21: To test effectiveness of the symptom-focused DM intervention, compared to a control group focused on weight management and diet skills training
RCT; 3-group experimental design; 5 rural counties in the southeast; 180 AAW, mean age 67 y, DM 12 y, mean A1C 8.3%, income < $15,000/y; 8.2% experienced DM symptoms

Over 9 mo: four 60-min counseling sessions; bimonthly home visits by nurse; 4 modules addressing symptoms of hyper- and hypoglycemia, numbness/tingling in the feet, and prevention of cardio symptoms; 4 phone booster calls, 15 min, 2-3/mo for 12 wk. Attentional control condition group: weight and diet program 4 modules, 60-min sessions for weight maintenance, modifying fat and Na, including counting carbohydrates, reading labels, portion sizes, healthy fats, decr saturated fat with exercises, shopping list, and recipes
A1C, symptom distress, quality of life via Problem Areas in Diabetes Survey + quality of life in DM scale; DMSC practices questionnaire

No significant difference between groups in any area. However, entire sample had significant improvement in A1C P = 0.1, symptom distress at 9 mo P < .01. mental and social well-being P < .01. PAID P < .01. DMSC practices no SS effect.
Two Feathers et al26: Is there a significant diabetes-related knowledge and behavioral changes, and glycemic control in AA and Latinos?
1-group pretest/posttest design in Detroit, Michigan; 111 participants, 64% AA, 80% female, mean age 59 y, mean A1C 8.4%

5 mo, five 2-h group meetings every 4 wk on DM, stress, stress reduction, and depression. PA, incr fruits/vegetables, decr dietary fat and sugar intake, behavioral changes; delivery by community workers
Knowledge questionnaires on diet, exercise and blood glucose control. Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance survey. Summary of DMSC activities questionnaire. A1C, BP, total chol, weight, height

Incr in knowledge of healthy eating and DM (P = .013), SS incr in vegetable consumption (P = .001), pouring fat off meats (P = .001), decr in soda/fruit beverage (P < .001), healthy eating plan (P = .004). No significant change in PA. SS improved A1C (P < .0001 AA). No significant changes in BP, weight, chol
Mayer-Davis et al19: To develop, implement, and evaluate a 1-y primary care–based lifestyle intervention for weight management that to improved metabolic control
RCT; 2 health centers in South Carolina; 152: 82% AA, 80% female, mean age 60 y, DM 11 y, average BMI = 36.7, 48% < high school

12 mo, 2 intervention groups: intensive lifestyle intervention: meet weekly for 4 mo for nutrition, then biweekly for 2 mo, and 1/mo for 6 mo; included behavioral strategies (diet modification of regularly consumed foods); reimbursable-lifestyle intervention: four 1-h sessions +3 group sessions + 1 individual session
At 3, 6, 12 mo: weight loss, height, BMI; secondary: A1C, lipid profile (total chol, HDL, LDL, TG), BP

Weight loss at 6 mo intensive lifestyle intervention group (P < .0001). No significant difference with other 2 groups. Weight loss at 12 mo intensive lifestyle intervention group weight loss was 2.2 kg (P < .003); 0.3 kg for usual care (P = .005). No significant difference between reimbursable-lifestyle intervention group and usual care groups at 12 mo. A1C: Usual care group decline of 1.1 points (P < .01), intensive lifestyle intervention group 1.6-point decline (P < .01), and reimbursable-lifestyle intervention group 0.8-point decline (P < .05). Secondary measures: No significant difference between intensive and usual care groups or between reimbursable and usual care groups—all groups improved modestly.
Rimmer et al28: To determine if a group of low-income, low-education AAW could improve health outcomes with a carefully structured health promotion intervention
Quasi-experimental single-group pretest-posttest design in Chicago, Illinois; 30: 80%AA, 80% female, mean age 54.9 y, 47% < high school
12 wk: 3 days/wk for 3 h; exercise, health education by RN and nutrition by RD, each for 1 h
A1C, total chol, lipid panel, exercise (physical), strength, nutrition (dietary fat intake, 7-day FFQ, nutrition knowledge, self-efficacy for eating a low-fat diet)

Decr in total chol (P < .03), LDL (P < .005). No significant changes in HDL, triglycerides, BS, weight, or A1C. Incr in cardiovascular fitness (P < .01) and muscular strength (P < .0001). Nutrition, SS in Rate Your Plate Scale (P < .01), self-efficacy (P < .001), and percent fat intake (P < .05)
Keyserling et al16,17: To improve dietary and physical activity behaviors of AAW with type 2 DM
RCT; clinic vs clinic + community vs control; 7 practices in central North Carolina; 200 AAW, mean age 59 y, DM 10.5 y, mean A1C 11.1
4 clinic-based visits, 12 telephone contacts, and 3 group sessions focusing on diet (provided by nutritionist), physical activity, and diabetes care education, 6-mo and 1-y follow-up
Dietary risk assessment, PA assessment, with Caltrac accelerometer, A1C, lipids, weight, DM knowledge, mental well-being, social well-being

Group comparison: PA at 12 mo A vs C P = .019, at 6 mo B vs C P = .036; no SS A vs B; decr in all groups but not SS for intake of saturated fat, chol, and total energy intake (P = .98, P = .18, P = .85); all participants gained weight (group P = .52), little effect on A1C and HDL (P values of .73, .51, and .15, respectively)
Mayer-Davis et al18: To confirm feasibility and the effects of a research-based weight loss intervention
RCT; rural medically underserved community, South Carolina; 96%AA and 82% female, average age 64.03 y, average BMI = 37.9
8 wk: 2 individual and 6 group sessions by interventionist discussing low-calorie/low-fat diet, moderate physical activity
Weight, height, BMI, and FBS
78% lost weight at 8 wk (both groups P < .05). BMI (−0.44 ± 0.71, P = .01). Significant improvements in BG (−24.23 ± 48.24 mg/dL, P = 05)
Agurs-Collins et al5: To evaluate a culturally appropriate weight loss and exercise program designed to improve DM in older AA.
RCT; urban hospital in Washington, DC; 64 AA, mostly women, 55-79 y, A1C > 10%
Over 6 mo: 12 weekly group sessions, 60 min nutrition education by RD, 30 min of exercise by exercise physiologist; 1 individual diet counseling session by 3 mo of biweekly group sessions
A1C, lipid levels, BP, weight, BMI, and height; 1-wk FFQ and nutrition knowledge questionnaire, PA scale for elderly

At 6 mo, decr in weight (women P = .007 and men P = .026), A1C (women P < .001 and men P < .01). Chol and HDL no significant difference. BP (P < .10); incr in PA (P = 0.001 overall and women P = .001); significant improvement in nutritional knowledge and nutrient intake at 3 mo but decrease to nonsignificant at 6 mo.
McNabb et al27: To test a culturally appropriate long-term weight loss program for AAW
Quasi-experimental; 13 AAW, mean age 57, DM 9 y, mean BMI = 34.2
12 weekly session on nutrition and to encourage 20-30 min PA a week, follow by 6 group sessions
Weight, A1C, BMI, non-FBS
At 1-y follow-up, decr in weight (from 205.7 to 195.9 lb, P < .008), BMI (P < .008). Decr in A1C at end of study (from 12.8% to 10.2%, P < .001) but incr at 1-y follow-up
Nutrition plus multifaceted care skills
Walker et al24: To assess the effectiveness of a DM educational intervention aimed at incr self-management behaviors

Quasi-experimental; self-selection to intervention and comparison groups. Prince George’s county, Washington, DC; 195 AA, intervention group 145: 80% female, mean age 61.86, DM 44.8% > 11 y; control group 50: 80% female, mean age 58.3 y, DM 25% > 11 y
Three 2-h intervention sessions: session 1, information on diabetes; session 2, diet and exercise; session 3, medication

DM knowledge questionnaire, DM Self-efficacy Outcomes Expectancies Questionnaire, Problem Areas in Diabetes Survey, exercise, benefits/barriers scale; sociopsychological; biological; BMI, A1C, frequency of exercise, stages of change

Significant incr in DM knowledge questionnaire scores (P = .00) for intervention group from baseline to 6-mo follow-up but no SS between group for baseline to follow-up score. Intervention group: decr in A1C that was > 7% (41.9% to 39.4%). No difference between groups on high to moderate level of self-efficacy. Perceived problems related to DM; 2/5 of intervention group perceived many barriers
Samuel-Hodge et al20: To promote changes in dietary, PA, medication adherence, self-monitoring of blood glucose; support for self-management behaviors; build church’s capacity to incr DM awareness.
Group RCT; 24 AA churches in North Carolina; 201 AA: 2/3 female, most completed high school, DM 9 y; mean A1C 7.8
12 biweekly group sessions 90-120 min + 15 min of PA and taste testing of recipes; 1-h counseling visit with RD for each participant; church DM advisor conducted monthly phone calls
Data collected at 8 and 12 mo; A1C, weight, BP, PA (Actigraph), FFQ, DM knowledge

8 mo, A1C significant difference between groups (P = .009) but nonsignificant difference at 12 mo (P = .33). No significant difference between groups with dietary except in percentage of calories from trans fats (P = .05). At 12 mo little change in light and moderate PA. Significant difference in diastolic BP (P < .001), DM knowledge (P = .003). No significant difference in general health status. Mental well-being (P = .004)
Utz et al29: Evaluate a tailored intervention for rural AA, group versus individual DSME.
Quasi-experimental design; randomly assigned to group or individual DSME. Community center in Virginia; 22 AA, 76% female, mean age 60 y, sixth grade–PhD, DM 9 y

Group DSME held weekly for 2 h over 8 weeks; individual DSME 3 times over 8 weeks by CDE. DSME had 7 areas: covered healthy eating, being active, monitoring, taking meds, problem solving, reducing risks, and healthy coping
At baseline and 10 wk; A1C, self-care actions, self-efficacy, goal achievement; 7 self-care behavior tracking, daily actions for DMSC and satisfaction

No SS group differences in outcome but clinical improvement in these measures: in the group DSME (A1C, −0.32, improved carbohydrate spacing +2.27) vs individual (A1C –0.24, decr in carbohydrate spacing > −0.14). There was statistical trend in foot care; group DSME showed more improvement. Goal attainment P = .129
D’eramo Melkus et al25: To test the feasibility of a culturally competent intervention of education and care for black women with type 2 DM
Quasi-experimental pretest/posttest, in General Clinical Research Center; 25 AAW, average age 52 y, DM 5.4 y, mean A1C 8%, high school, mean income < $15,000

6 weekly group meetings included proper blood glucose meter use, DM education, PA, goal attainment, macronutrient composition of food groups, cultural barriers to dietary change and weight control; diet behaviors, recipes, calories, reading food labels, meaning of food. Monthly visits by advanced practice RNs to reinforce content.
At baseline, 3-mo postintervention; DM knowledge, self-efficacy outcome expectancies, distress using Problem Areas in DM; height, weight, BMI, A1C

Significant improvement of A1C from 8% to 6.9% (P = .002); significant difference in BMI (P = .005); nonsignificant difference in DM knowledge; significant difference in DM emotional distress (P = .01)

fn.p: Abbreviations: AA, African Americans; A1C, hemoglobin A1C%; AAW, African American women; BMI, body mass index; BP, blood pressure; chol, cholesterol; decr, decrease; DM, diabetes; DMSC, diabetes self-care; DSME, diabetes self-management education; FBG, fasting blood glucose; FFQ, Food Frequency Questionnaire; incr, increase; PA, physical activity; RCT, randomized control trial; RD, registered dietitian; SS, statistically significant; mo, months; wk, week; h, hours.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: A total of 390 abstracts were reviewed and compared to the inclusion and exclusion criteria. Most abstracts were eliminated on review of their title or contents. Twenty-four abstracts were selected for a second level of review, and 11 met the inclusion criteria. Two additional studies were obtained from “related articles” offered by the PubMed database. Two additional studies were gained from the ancestry searches of the 11 studies’ reference lists. The search strategies yielded a total of 15 intervention studies for this review. The 15 studies included randomized controlled trials and quasi-experimental designs.

sec.title: Characteristics of the Studies
sec.p: The characteristics of the studies are listed in Table 1. Of the 15 studies, 7 studies3,5,16,18-21 were randomized controlled trials, and 8 studies22-29 used quasi-experimental designs. All studies were conducted within the United States, in various settings that included primary care practices, community centers, and participants’ homes. Sample sizes ranged from 13 to 648 participants. African Americans composed 64% to 100% of the participants, and 65% to 100% of the participants were women. In 4 studies, 100% of the participants were African American women.16,21,25,27

sec.title: Types of Interventions
sec.p: There was a wide variety in characteristics of the interventions in terms of topics, location, and delivery strategies. The interventions were delivered in group sessions3,16,18-20,22-29 and individual sessions,3,5,16,18-21,25,29 using didactic methods5,25,28 and group discussions,22,23,25,27,28 and included in-person23,28 or telephone follow-up sessions.16,20-23 Sessions were conducted by a nurse,21,28 a nurse–case manager,22,23 an advanced practice nurse,25 a registered dietitian (or nutritionist),* a certified diabetes educator,28,29 or a trained lay community worker.16,20,26 Several studies used interactive activities, such as ethnic food models,3,22, 23 hands-on cooking demonstrations and tastings of low-fat meals,16,20,22,23,28,29 reading of food labels,5,21-25,29 and games.20,24

For analysis, we classified the interventions into 3 categories: those focusing on (1) diet or nutrition only, (2) weight management by diet and physical activity, and (3) multifaceted diabetes education that addressed diet and physical activity and other self-management behaviors, such as blood glucose monitoring and taking medication. Only 3 studies3,22,23 focused on dietary changes alone. Dietary-only interventions taught participants to plan and prepare healthy low-fat meals during hands-on cooking sessions and to make healthy selections when dining out. These interventions included class and group discussions, and 2 of these studies22,23 provided follow-up phone calls and home visits by a nurse case manager. Each of the 3 studies provided 4 education sessions ranging from 30 to 90 minutes over a 6- to 12-month period.

Eight† interventions focused on weight management (diet and physical activity) to control T2DM. In addition to the components addressed in the dietary only interventions, the weight management studies addressed increasing fruit and vegetable consumption and decreasing portion sizes. These interventions also engaged participants in 15 to 60 minutes of physical activity per session, and the sessions ranged from 3 group sessions to 12 weekly sessions.

Four studies20,24,25,29 tested multifaceted diabetes self-management interventions. These studies not only examined dietary changes and physical activity but also built skills in blood glucose monitoring, medication taking, and problem solving. The sessions ranged from once a week for 8 weeks to twice a week for 12 weeks. Of these studies, only 1 provided a time range for the sessions, which lasted from 90 to 120 minutes for each of the 12 biweekly group sessions.20

sec.title: Measures Taken
sec.p: The 15 studies used several instruments to measure the effects of the culturally competent interventions on self-care. The most common self-care skills measured were food habits and physical activity. Eight‡ of the 15 studies evaluated nutritional intake or dietary habits, even though all of them had a dietary component within the intervention. Diet and nutritional intake were measured with the Food Frequency Questionnaire,3,5,20,28 Food Habit Questionnaire,22,23 Dietary Risk Assessment,16 and 24-hour recall.3 Measurements were also made of nutritional knowledge5,26,28 and change in consumption of vegetables,26 soda,26 fruit beverages,26 fats,3,23,26,28 or sugary foods.3

Physical activity was measured either as knowledge about physical activity and its effects on diabetes control or as actual physical activity completed. Physical activity knowledge was measured with the Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance Survey,26 the Physical Activity Scale for the Elderly Questionnaire,5 the Diabetes Self-Care Practices questionnaire,21 and Exercise Benefits/Barriers Scale with the Level of Exercise Stages of Change.24 Actual physical activity was measured using of the Actigraph monitor20; symptom-limited graded exercise test (peak VO2 and heart rate), LifeFitness28; and an accelerometer.16

All the studies focused on improving diabetes control in African Americans, and all measured A1C except one, which measured fasting blood glucose.18 Other health outcomes evaluated were blood pressure,3,5,19,20,23,26 weight or body mass index,5,18,19,22-27 and total cholesterol and its components.§ Intervention effects were also captured with measurements of self-care actions,29 self-efficacy,24,25,28,29 goal achievement,29 cost of care,23 and mental and social well-being.16

sec.title: Major Findings
sec.p: Although the interventions affected a variety of self-care skills and health outcomes, this literature review focuses on dietary outcomes, weight loss, changes in metabolic control (A1C), lipids, blood pressure, and cholesterol that resulted from the interventions.

sec.title: Dietary Outcomes
sec.p: Seven of the 9 studies3,5,22-24,26,28 that measured dietary changes showed significant reductions in calories taken in from dietary fats3,22,23,26,28 and increased nutritional knowledge.5,24,26 Three of these 7 studies were those that delivered a dietary-focused intervention3,22,23; 3 were among those that delivered a weight focused intervention5,26,28; and 1 was among the 4 that delivered a multifaceted intervention.24 Of the 2 studies that did not demonstrate a statistically significant improvement in food practices, 1 delivered a weight loss intervention16 and 1 a multifaceted intervention.20

Of the 7 studies that produced significant improvements in food practices, only 2—a dietary-focused intervention22 and a weight-focused intervention26—teased out differences between sex and race. Anderson-Loftin et al22 reported that among the 100% African American participants, men had a significantly larger decrease in dietary fat intake than the women. However, Two Feathers et al26 reported that African American women showed better improvement with dietary behaviors, such as vegetable and whole grain bread consumption and pouring off fat, compared to African American men and Latino men and women.

sec.title: Weight Management
sec.p: All 8 weight-focused interventions, as well as 1 multifaceted25 intervention, measured and reported weight changes. Five studies5,18,19,25,27 showed statistically significant weight loss from interventions that addressed diet and physical activity. Of the 7 studies that measured physical activity,‖ only 3 studies—2 interventions focusing on weight management21,26 and 1 multifaceted intervention29—did not produce statically significant changes in physical activity. Keyserling et al16 showed significant improvements in physical activity for participants in both interventions groups (clinic and clinic plus community) versus the control group yet reported a net weight gain among all participants. Mayer-Davis et al,19 who provided more education sessions for physical activity and nutrition over the same study duration as Keyserling et al,16 showed significant weight loss among their participants in both intervention groups versus the control group.

sec.title: Health Outcomes: Cholesterol and Blood Pressure
sec.p: Nine¶ studies measured physiologic health outcomes, such as total cholesterol, LDL, HDL, triglycerides, or blood pressure. Seven studies—including the 3 dietary studies3,22,23 and 4 weight loss interventions5,16,19,26—did not demonstrate statistically significant improvements of LDL or blood pressure levels. However, one of the diet-focused studies3 showed a statistically significant increase in HDL for both groups. Of the 6 studies that measured blood pressure changes,3,5,19,20,23,26 only 1 multifaceted study20 showed significant improvement in blood pressure.

sec.title: Glycemic Control
sec.p: A1C was the most common measure of all the studies. Six studies5,20,23,25-27 attained statistically significant decreases in A1C, and 1 study18 reduced fasting blood glucose. Three studies—1 dietary22 and 2 weight loss16,28—showed little or no effect in glycemic control. Authors of these 3 studies provided possible reasons, including participants beginning with relatively low A1C values,22 no emphases on medication adherence or blood glucose monitoring,16 short study duration time,28 and small sample size.28

sec.title: Barriers
sec.p: The authors noted barriers to participants’ adherence to proper diabetes care and study participation. Noted barriers were having less than high school–level education26,28 and low socioeconomic status,26,28,29 participants’ multiple concurrent illnesses,21,28,29 lack of family support,28 unsafe neighborhoods for exercise,5,23,26,28 multicaregiving duties,19,21 feelings of dietary deprivation,19 and fear of diabetes complications.19

sec.title: Cultural Competence Definition
sec.p: Cultural competence, or tailoring, is defined as “the process of creating culturally sensitive interventions, often involving the adaptation of existing materials and programs for racial/ethnic subpopulation.”31(p11) Culturally sensitive interventions may include surface and deep structures.31 Surface structures are superficial aspects, such as addressing people, places, food, and clothing preferred by the targeted population, whereas deep structures involve addressing cultural, historical, or environmental forces that influence the targeted population.31

Most of the studies stated that they used a culturally competent intervention to affect physiologic factors associated with T2DM for African Americans. Some of the 15 studies included either a formal definition of cultural competence that contained both surface and deep structures or reference,5,22,23,26,29 and some addressed only surface structure in the form of a reference to culturally appropriate materials.16,18,19,20,25,27 For instance, Anderson-Loftin et al22,23 provided a definition that consisted of both dimensions of culturally sensitive interventions. They described their intervention as using “cultural competent approaches [that incorporated] ethnic beliefs, values, customs, food patterns, language, and health care practices of southern [rural African Americans].”23(p247) The Anderson-Loftin et al23 intervention used ethnic food models and typical food preferences in cooking demonstration framed around social events, and it encouraged family members’ participation. Five studies16,19-21,25 referred to culturally appropriate materials for the interventions but did not provide a formal definition of cultural competence. These interventions included a notebook or cookbook with food guides, with ethnic foods and recipes that were low in cost, fat, and cholesterol in the preparations; or, educational materials reflected language and social values. Three studies neither defined cultural competence nor addressed surface or deep structural elements.3,24,28 Studies that provided cultural competence did not result in better diabetes outcomes than did studies that did not provide a definition or referred to culturally appropriate materials.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Few interventions are culturally relevant self-care interventions designed to treat T2DM among African American women. Only 15 studies since 1989 were found for this review. Those reviewed demonstrated mixed results in the areas of diet, weight management, and physiologic outcomes, but most significantly improved glycemic control. The studies that did not report statistically significant results mentioned some of the barriers noted above, such as dietary deprivation and the traditional African American diet, which may have affected results. Because some of the studies reviewed were pilot studies,18,25,27,29 they predicted better results with more participants and more time for the intervention.

Most interventions improved dietary habits; fewer affected physical activity; and physiologic improvements in weight, lipids, and blood pressure were achieved less often. Only 3 studies3,22,23 focused on dietary changes to improve glycemic control with African American women; furthermore, 2 of these studies were done by the same research team. This is somewhat surprising given the impact of proper dietary modification on glycemic control. Although African American women are heavily affected by T2DM, only 4 studies comprised all women.16,21,25,27 Of the 11 studies that included men and women, only four studies5,19,22,26 compared findings between the sexes; 3 studies5,19,22 reported mixed effects of the interventions on men’s and women’s weight loss, while the study by Two Feathers et al26 reported effects of the intervention on men’s and women’s food consumption.

It is not clear what components of the 15 interventions were most effective. Most studies did not report the duration of the sessions, thereby making comparison of “intervention dose” impossible. In addition, variations across the studies in content and methods used do not point to specific recommendations for clinicians or educators to adopt or avoid.

Most interventions addressed dietary changes in combination with physical activity or other aspects of diabetes self-management education. It is possible that the amount of varied information is overwhelming and the interventions would be more effective if they focused exclusively on dietary changes, the most challenging aspect of diabetes management. Research reports should clearly identify quantity and quality of interventions. Further research on culturally appropriate dietary interventions developed for African Americans, specifically for women, should be tested because a better understanding of the impact of cultural food practices could lead to better dietary guidelines for a population that is suffering from such a costly and debilitating disease. The feasibility of the research should be determined by future researchers.
